articles.headline: Bankers Say Rules Are the Problem
articles.snippet: Blaming mark-to-market accounting for the financial crisis is like blaming the weathermen for a hurricane.
articles.abstract: Blaming mark-to-market accounting for the financial crisis is like blaming the weathermen for a hurricane.
articles.lead_paragraph: If mark-to-market accounting is to blame for the current financial crisis, then the National Weather Service is to blame for Hurricane Katrina; if it hadn’t told us the hurricane hit New Orleans, the city would never have flooded.

articles.headline: A Besieged Bank, and Its Hometown, Look Inward
articles.snippet: In Charlotte, N.C., where Bank of America casts a long shadow, there is concern about the bank’s leadership.
articles.abstract: In Charlotte, N.C., where Bank of America casts a long shadow, there is concern about the bank’s leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Each workday, when the closing bell sounds on Wall Street, the mayor here in the Wall Street of the South takes stock of this city’s fortunes.

articles.headline: As Indian Growth Soars, Child Hunger Persists
articles.snippet: Malnutrition is worse in India than in many sub-Saharan African countries.
articles.abstract: Malnutrition is worse in India than in many sub-Saharan African countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Small, sick, listless children have long been India’s scourge  “a national shame,” in the words of its prime minister, Manmohan Singh. But even after a decade of galloping economic growth, child malnutrition rates are worse here than in many sub-Saharan African countries, and they stand out as a paradox in a proud democracy.

articles.headline: Congresswoman, Tied to Bank, Helped Seek Funds
articles.snippet: Maxine Waters facilitated contact between regulators and a bank chief with ties to her family seeking bailout funds.
articles.abstract: Maxine Waters facilitated contact between regulators and a bank chief with ties to her family seeking bailout funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Top federal regulators say they were taken aback when they learned that a California congresswoman who helped set up a meeting with bankers last year had family financial ties to a bank whose chief executive asked them for up to $50 million in special bailout funds.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Obama on Spot Over a Benefit to Gay Couples
articles.snippet: President Obama must decide whether to provide health insurance to same-sex partners of federal employees.
articles.abstract: President Obama must decide whether to provide health insurance to same-sex partners of federal employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just seven weeks into office, President Obama is being forced to confront one of the most sensitive social and political issues of the day: whether the government must provide health insurance benefits to same-sex partners of federal employees.

articles.headline: Forget Britney; Media Outrage Hits Big Spenders
articles.snippet: The tabloid media is expanding to the likes of Bernard L. Madoff, tapping into populist anger at corporate America.
articles.abstract: The tabloid media is expanding to the likes of Bernard L. Madoff, tapping into populist anger at corporate America.
articles.lead_paragraph: It could be called “To Catch a Rich Guy.”

articles.headline: Europe’s Way of Encouraging Solar Power Arrives in the U.S.
articles.snippet: The strategy is to pay homeowners and businesses top dollar for producing green energy.
articles.abstract: The strategy is to pay homeowners and businesses top dollar for producing green energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Solar cells adorn the roofs of many homes and warehouses across Germany, while the bright white blades of wind turbines are a frequent sight against the sky in Spain.

articles.headline: Household Wealth Falls by Trillions
articles.snippet: American households lost 9 percent of their wealth in the last three months of 2008, the most in 57 years since the central bank began its tracking.
articles.abstract: American households lost 9 percent of their wealth in the last three months of 2008, the most in 57 years since the central bank began its tracking.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last few months, most Americans have felt poorer. Now they have the numbers to prove it.

articles.headline: Testing Firm Finds Itself Being Tested
articles.snippet: A Colorado company that oversees clinical studies said it was the victim of a Congressional subcommittee’s sting operation.
articles.abstract: A Colorado company that oversees clinical studies said it was the victim of a Congressional subcommittee’s sting operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like other federal undercover operations, this one had the usual trappings, like a company whose address turned out to be a P.O. box in a strip shopping mall and a businessman whose credentials proved fraudulent.

articles.headline: China’s Leader Says He Is ‘Worried’ Over U.S. Treasuries
articles.snippet: The Chinese premier, Wen Jiabao, expressed concern on Friday about China’s $1 trillion investment in U.S. government debt.
articles.abstract: The Chinese premier, Wen Jiabao, expressed concern on Friday about China’s $1 trillion investment in U.S. government debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese prime minister, Wen Jiabao, spoke in unusually blunt terms on Friday about the “safety” of China’s $1 trillion investment in American government debt, the world’s largest such holding, and urged the Obama administration to offer assurances that the securities would maintain their value.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines, Keith Bradsher and Mark Landler
